title: Ticket #2968: submit should modify requirements when request_cpus is non-zero
description:
condor_submit should add 
(TARGET.Cpus >= RequestCpus)
when the submit file defines a value for request_cpus.
remarks:
2012-May-02 20:29:48 by johnkn:
note: the checkin for this fix also fixes the problem reported by igor

  • too many/undesired warnings about Memory in Requirements
  • no way to disable having RequestMemory added to Requirements.

there is now a config knob (not yet added to param_info.in) ENABLE_DEPRECATION_WARNINGS

Also, 

RequestMemory = undefined
no longer results in a explicit RequestMemory attribute with a value of undefined being added to the job ad. And also, this disables the adding of RequestMemory to Requirements. Setting the value of RequestMemory to 0 also disables adding to Requirements The same logic also applies to RequestDisk and RequestCpus

-tj

2012-May-03 09:57:26 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • In SetMachineCount(), if RequireCpus is set to undefined or if no value can be found for it, the previous contents of buffer (if any) is inserted a second time. To avoid this, move the InsertJobExpr() call at the end of the function up to each place buffer is set.

  • In SetImageSize(), request_memory in the submit file can be fancy (e.g. 2.2G), but JOB_DEFAULT_REQUESTMEMORY cannot. The same is true for request_disk and JOB_DEFAULT_REQUESTDISK). This is likely to be confusing to users.

  • Adding a (TARGET.Cpus>=RequestCpus) clause to Requirements breaks scheduler and local universes (Nathan tripped over this this morning). We should add a Cpus attribute to the schedd ad used to match these jobs.

2012-May-03 10:55:38 by jfrey:
Code Review

It looks like your new changes fix the RequestCpus requirements problem and the InsertJobExpr() problem.
